docs.lead_paragraph: They have been called assassins and parasites. They receive hate mail from the proponents of a variety of popular psychotherapies. The president-elect of the American Psychological Association has accused them of being overly devoted to the scientific method. But the ire of their colleagues has not prevented a small, loosely organized band of academic psychologists from rooting out and publicly debunking mental health practices that they view as faddish, unproved or in some cases potentially harmful.

headline.main: Defying Psychiatric Wisdom, These Skeptics Say 'Prove It'

docs.abstract: In 1988, psychology Professor Scott Lilienfeld and colleagues, concerned that American Psychological Assn was not putting enough emphasis on scientific methods of diagnosis and treatment, formed American Psychological Society; maverick group, which now has 15,000 members, cites lack of data to support many practices in use; critics of new organization say many members have financial interest in scientific point of view and some are paid to testify in court; consensus between groups over validity and benefits of two forms of psychotherapy, cognitive behavioral therapy and interpersonal therapy, discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: They have been called assassins and parasites. They receive hate mail from the proponents of a variety of popular psychotherapies. The president-elect of the American Psychological Association has accused them of being overly devoted to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: They push their peas around the plate, turn up their noses at chicken parmesan and won't even consider broccoli. But is picky eating among young children really something to be concerned about? Apparently not, say Finnish researchers who found few meaningful differences between the diets of children described by their parents as poor eaters and those of other children. ''Our findings suggest that even though parental complaints of poor eating in children are very common, there appears to be no reason for serious concern,'' Susanna Saarilehto of the University of Turku and her colleagues wrote. The study is in the current issue of The Journal of Pediatrics. In the study, parents of almost 500 5-year-olds were asked about their children's eating habits. Children whose parents said they ate too little ''sometimes'' or ''often'' were classified as poor eaters (the definition included picky eaters and children who did not eat a lot). Parents were then asked to record everything their children ate over a four-day period. Poor eaters tended to be a little shorter and weigh a little less than the others. But they also tended to have been smaller at birth, raising the possibility that they simply required less food. In fact, when food intake was adjusted for weight, it was about the same for each group. One difference was found between the groups: the poor eaters got more of their calories from snacks than from meals. Still, the researchers said, at that age, children generally adjust their eating over the course of a day so they take in the right amount of food.

headline.main: Young Broccoli Haters Get a Break

docs.abstract: Susanna Saarilehto, University of Turku, Finland, researcher, leads study on childhood diets that finds no discernible differences in health of poor or picky eaters and good eaters; drawing (S)
